snippet.textDisplay:
How much carbon it takes to manufacture solar panels and wind turbines and how long do they last? Then you have to do the batteries for storage and cost of clearing land to place solar and wind. Not sure it’s any better than coal or natural gas. And you can see when countries switch to more green tech their co2 output ends up increasing because that have to start and stop the conventional power plants when wind and solar fall short (see Germany). You also see around a 20% increase in cost.

We have the answer it’s nuclear power but that one not on the table. I get why but until we invent more efficient green energy that’s our only option.
snippet.textOriginal:
How much carbon it takes to manufacture solar panels and wind turbines and how long do they last?  Then you have to do the batteries for storage and cost of clearing land to place solar and wind.  Not sure it’s any better than coal or natural gas.  And you can see when countries switch to more green tech their co2 output ends up increasing because that have to start and stop the conventional power plants when wind and solar fall short (see Germany). You also see around a 20% increase in cost.

We have the answer it’s nuclear power but that one not on the table.  I get why but until we invent more efficient green energy that’s our only option.

snippet.textDisplay:
Law of conservation of mass.
Carbon is inevitable.
To eliminate carbon would result in a barren planet.
No trees, plants, animals or humans.
In fact, of the estimated 40,000 metric tons of comic dust the earth gathers, a portion has to be carbon.

snippet.textDisplay:
Rich people make me paranoid when spreading their message of pollution. It's usually an undertone of: You should be ashamed of yourself, you should not exist and so on. Not the real issues of pollution, which are; poverty, careless corporations, governmental neglect and stuff like that. Most of the pollution in the world is caused by normal people, but because of lack of easy solutions.


Simply put: It is our governments' responsibility to provide solutions, because we're already PAYING for those solutions.

snippet.textDisplay:
I am neutral on this stuff. But logical: Lets go through a few lessons: (long read, but common sense).
1. Lets put up wind farms all over the place in big numbers. - Lets melt steel that costs thousands of dollars and burns up tons of electricity and strips the earth of mining materials to make them.

2. Lets mandate DOC, DPF and SCR filters on semi trucks. We manufacture DEF fluid, heavily stripmine the earth for trace minerals of PLATINUM and fast-idle trucks for 40 minutes burning FUEL to do a REGEN of the DPF. And NOW the truck gets 1.5mpg on climbing hills instead of 5.

3. Hydrogen engines are great and I will agree they work GOOD. But instead of auto companies offering retrofit programs. They want us to create MORE waste and greenhouse gases. Pushing us into BUYING ANOTHER vehicle that has to be MADE from more earth materials. - Any auto company can retrofit a motor for a vehicle. They just chose NOT to.
4. Lets use nasty paper straws that are CUT from trees and degrade when used. Plastic actually does not cut down trees.

5. Lets sort our recycle bins. - How about form groups to go sort LANDFILLS, where the problem EXISTS.

6. Lets talk about PUSHING for environmental activism. - Where's your solar panel on your house? A simple grid tie system costs 300 bucks and yet NOBODY does it.

7. lets NOT explore the option of more train transportation and only take airplanes that SPEW burnt fuel into the atmosphere at 30,000 plus feet in the air.

8. Lets mandate EPA changes and requirements for all citizens. - Citizens no longer can afford to pay bills and buy food. "but it is good for the environment"... "but there are homeless people whom are starving.. but.. it is.. GOOD for the environment. Yeah, just ask every person that cannot get a mortgage and/or afford their BILLS for clean and running water. Thank you EPA for making sewage processing and water meters expensive.

9. Our nations healthcare sucks.. nobody can afford to shower as often or wash their hands.

10. Our nations healthcare is really bad. Plastic IV bags, sterile medical tubes cost too much due to taxes on plastic..

--Did you enjoy this discussion? I sure did! If you were offended by ANY of these grammatical spelling errors. The internetz is NOT for u. meme life.

snippet.textDisplay: I admire Bill Gates' commitment to cleaner energy sources, but he should focus more on improving the negative public opinion of nuclear power. I know he's a pro-nuclear guy, but it's really unpopular with people who supposedly care about the environment. This probably won't ever happen now that America is balls deep in that sweet sweet shale oil, but I would like to see large-scale efforts made to portray nuclear power in a more favorable light moving forward.
snippet.textOriginal: I admire Bill Gates' commitment to cleaner energy sources, but he should focus more on improving the negative public opinion of nuclear power. snippet.textDisplay: 100 companies are responsible for 77% of carbon emissions. Individual actions are fine, but I think--somewhat like what you said in the video--the problem can only be solved on collective level. China's electric buses are displacing more oil than all electric cars in the world combined. And they have 99% of the electric buses in the world and they put out more new ones than London has every week. China is running headlong toward solutions and we should copy them.
snippet.textOriginal: 100 companies are responsible for 77% of carbon emissions. Individual actions are fine, but I think--somewhat like what you said in the video--the problem can only be solved on collective level. China's electric buses are displacing more oil than all electric cars in the world combined. And they have 99% of the electric buses in the world and they put out more new ones than London has every week. China is running headlong toward solutions and we should copy them.

snippet.textDisplay: One of the programs that Bill Gates is helping fund and which I believe has the best chance of reducing carbon emissions is the construction of 4th generation nuclear reactors. By using Thorium instead of Uranium and using a molten salt reactors, it is physically impossible for a nuclear meltdown to occur, while it would produce as much as 200x the energy a normal nuclear reactor can produce, all while producing zero carbon emissions. There's enough Thorium to power the entire world for almost 1000 years, and it can produce energy 24/7/365,  unlike solar power.
snippet.textOriginal: One of the programs that Bill Gates is helping fund and which I believe has the best chance of reducing carbon emissions is the construction of 4th generation nuclear reactors. By using Thorium instead of Uranium and using a molten salt reactors, it is physically impossible for a nuclear meltdown to occur, while it would produce as much as 200x the energy a normal nuclear reactor can produce, all while producing zero carbon emissions. There's enough Thorium to power the entire world for almost 1000 years, and it can produce energy 24/7/365,  unlike solar power.

snippet.textDisplay: Driving an electric car in a country with renewable electricity does not save the world. You then use up electricity that would have been sent off to another country where they use fossil fuel to make electricity. If renewable power is used on my tesla it simply means someone in another country/place will use fossil fuel to heat up their home.

snippet.textDisplay:
he ignores the biggest CO2 per kg items. Food.... animal agriculture is bigger than all transportation sectors combined. A portion of lamb is nearly 40kg of CO2, beef burger is like 35kg of CO2. Then there’s the factors of land use, water use and crops fed to livestock. Ocean deadzones, deforestation (preventing co2 extraction) and species extinction. This video was an appeal to majority and didn’t display any significantly helpful information for individuals to be informed and act accordingly. Check out the oxford studies.


http://www.ox.ac.uk/news/2018-06-01-new-estimates-environmental-cost-food


http://www.ox.ac.uk/news/2018-10-12-balanced-plant-based-diets-improve-our-health-and-health-planet

Carbon cost of food - https://www.greeneatz.com/foods-carbon-footprint.html

snippet.textDisplay:
Amount of people displaced by climate change, ZERO! It used to be sea level rise was 0.4 mm per year. But you see that wasn't fast enough because Al Gores 20 feet would take 12,000 years and that's a very long time. Now NOAA says it's 0.2 cm/yr(1/8th inch), 24 cm since 1880. That's about 24 cm in a century or 10 inches. That's still not very much. You see storm surges can be up to 10 feet and seasonal tides that do cause mild flooding are 6-8 feet. That 10 inches, compared to a full moon with a offshore wind, is almost nothing.

We will find alternate power sources by the end of the century. It won't be wind or solar. But, do drive that electric car, it's way more efficient. Solars not bad it just doesn't work in the winter where most of our populations live.
snippet.textOriginal:
Amount of people displaced by climate change,  ZERO!  It used to be sea level rise was 0.4 mm per year.   But you see that wasn't fast enough because Al Gores 20 feet would take 12,000 years and that's a very long time.  Now NOAA says it's 0.2 cm/yr(1/8th inch), 24 cm since 1880.  That's about 24 cm in a century or 10 inches.   That's still not very much.  You see storm surges can be up to 10 feet and seasonal tides that do cause mild flooding are 6-8 feet.   That 10 inches, compared to a full moon with a offshore wind, is almost nothing.  

We will find alternate power sources by the end of the century.  It won't be wind or solar.  But, do drive that electric car, it's way more efficient.   Solars not bad it just doesn't work in the winter where most of our populations live.
